column1: His popularity with his schoolfellows was instant and decided. His good humor and lively disposition might readily account for that
column2: even if his position as the adopted son of a prominent citizen had no effect. But it was understood that the doctor
column3: who had no near relatives
column4: intended to treat Phil in all respects as a son
column5: even to leaving him his heir.It may be asked whether the padrone gave up all efforts to recover the young fiddler. He was too vindictive for this. Boys had run away from him before
column6: but none had subjected him to such ignominious failure in the effort for their recovery. It would have fared ill with our young hero if he had fallen again into the hands of his unscrupulous enemy. But the padrone was not destined to recover him. Day after day Pietro explored the neighboring towns
column7: but all to no purpose. He only visited the principal towns
column8: while Phil was in a small town
column9: not likely to attract the attention of his pursuers.A week after his signal failure in Newark
column10: the padrone inserted an advertisement in the New York Herald
column11: offering a reward of twenty-five dollars for the recovery of Phil. But our hero was at that time wandering about the country
column12: and the advertisement did not fall under the eyes of those with whom he came in contact. At length the padrone was compelled to own himself baffled and give up the search. He was not without hopes
column13: however
column14: that sometime Phil would turn up. He did hear of him again through Pietro
column15: but not in a way to bring him any nearer his recovery.An hour afterward
column16: while walking with the doctor in a side street
column17: Phil’s attention was attracted by the notes of a hand-organ. Turning in the direction from which they came
column18: he met the glance of his old enemy
column19: Pietro.Pietro had not been certain till then that it was Phil. It looked like him
column20: to be sure
column21: but his new clothing and general appearance made such a difference between him and the Phil of former days that he would have supposed it only an accidental resemblance. But Phil’s evident recognition of him convinced him of his identity. He instantly ceased playing
